But no equipment has been damaged.''</p><p>Trepanier said the low strain on Hydro-Quebec's network during summer makes it easier to re-route power in case of emergencies.</p><p>Approximately 50 forest fires are raging across the province, claiming 325 square kilometres of forest. The most important was in the Nemiscau region of James Bay, where 175 square kilometres of forest have burned since the fire began July 2.</p><p>The Nemiscau fire burned to within 800 metres of the village of Nemaska, where about 200 Cree aboriginals were evacuated by early Friday evening and another 250 were to be evacuated on Hydro-Quebec buses by Friday night, said Chantal Drapeau of the provincial forest fire protection service.</p><p>The evacuated people were taken to the towns of Eastmain and Wemindji, she added.</p><p>A lack of rain over the past few weeks has contributed to the fires, and Quebec is awaiting help from firefighters in Ontario and Manitoba.</p><p>Meanwhile, a helicopter being used to fight a fire in the Haute-Cote-Nord region made a rough landing Friday afternoon after its rear rotor struck a tree.</p><p>The pilot wasn't injured and the Quebec forest fire protection service helicopter sustained only minor damage. It was being used to transport equipment and firefighters to a fire about 150 kilometres northwest of Manic-5.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata "It's well within a quarter mile of the nearest homes in Floriston."</p><p>No homes were destroyed or damaged by evening. One firefighter was treated for heat exhaustion.</p><p>I-80 was closed at about 2:30 p.m. at the Nevada line after the fire jumped from the south side of the interstate to the north side.</p><p>Heavy smoke from the blaze caused poor visibility for motorists, and blanketed the Reno area about 19 kilometres to the east and the Carson Valley about 95 kilometres to the southeast.</p><p>The fire also forced the closure of the transcontinental rail line through the Truckee canyon used by both Union Pacific freight and Amtrak passenger trains.</p><p>Hoffmier said firefighters were being hampered by steep terrain and wind gusts of up to 40 km/h. The winds made the air attack difficult by blowing retardant off target.</p><p>"If the winds co-operate, we could stand a good chance of saving those homes," he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Our conservation officers are patrolling all the areas where the campers are and anybody caught will be charged,'' Legouffe said.</p><p>As of Thursday, there were 33 fires burning across the province.</p><p>Ontario has had 774 forest fires so far this year, with a total of about 10,000 hectares burned.</p><p>Those numbers are almost doubled from this time last year, when there were 406 opportunities,'' Cam Jackson said Friday in a written statement.</p><p> The services provided by these agencies help immigrants adapt more quickly and easily to their new B3Portugal forest fire death toll likely to rise; 'We are most likely facing the biggest tragedy of human life that we have known'Helena Alves And Armando FrancaThe Associated PressPEDROGAO GRANDE, Portugal -

A raging forest fire in central Portugal sent flames sweeping over roads, killing at least 61 people, many of them trapped in their cars as they tried to flee, officials said Sunday. The country's prime minister called it "the biggest tragedy" that Portugal has experienced in decades and declared three days of national mourning.

A huge wall of thick smoke and bright red flames towered over the top of trees in the forested Pedrogao Grande area some 150 kilometres northeast of Lisbon where a lightning strike was believed to have sparked the blaze Saturday. Investigators found a tree that was hit during a "dry thunderstorm," the head of the national judicial police told Portuguese media.

Dry thunderstorms are frequent when falling water evaporates before reaching the ground because of high temperatures. Portugal, like most southern European countries, is prone to forest fires in the dry summer months. At least four other significant wildfires affected different areas of the country on Sunday but the one in Pedrogao Grande was responsible for all the deaths.

"The dimensions of this fire have caused a human tragedy beyond any in our memory," said Prime Minister Antonio Costa told reporters on his arrival at the scene Sunday. "Something extraordinary has taken place and we have to wait for technicians to properly determine its causes."

He said the death toll was lowered from the previously reported 62 victims because one person had been counted twice. However, he added that "there's no point in feeling joyful for that, because surely we will find more victims as we progress." Police are searching charred areas of the forest and isolated homes for more bodies.

More than 350 soldiers on Sunday joined the 700 firefighters who have been struggling to put out the blaze. Authorities say temperatures as high as 40 degrees Celsius in the area in recent days might have also played a part in the inferno.

The forest fire deaths were the biggest in memory in Portugal, which saw 25 Portuguese soldiers die fighting wildfires in 1966. Last August, an outbreak of fires across Portugal killed four people, including three on the island of Madeira, and destroyed huge areas of forest.

Resident Isabel Brandao told The Associated Press that she had feared for her life when she saw the blaze.

"Yesterday we saw the fire but thought it was very far. I never thought it would come to this side," she said Sunday. "At 3:30 a.m., my mother-in-law woke me up quickly and we never went to sleep again. We were afraid the fire would reach us."

Other locals were also shocked. "This is a region that has had fires because of its forests, but we cannot remember a tragedy of these proportions," said Valdemar Alves, the mayor of Pedrogao Grande. "I am completely stunned by the number of deaths."

State broadcaster RTP showed terrifying images of several people on a road trying to escape the intense smoke that had reduced visibility to a few meters. A young man shared a bottle of water with a distraught woman as she stumbled down the road.

Interior Ministry official Jorge Gomes said firefighting crews were having difficulties battling the fire, which was "very intense" in at least two of its four fronts. He said authorities were worried about strong winds that could help spreading the blaze further.

Schools in the area were closed until further notice and outdoor fires were banned, authorities announced Sunday.

Gomes gave a grim description of the deaths to RTP. He said at least 30 people died inside their cars as they tried to flee between the towns of Figueiro dos Vinhos and Castanheira de Pera. He says 17 others died right outside their cars or by the road, 11 people died in the forest and two people died in a car accident related to the fire and information was missing on the other deaths.

Gomes says 54 people were also injured in the fire, 5 of them seriously, including four firefighters and a minor.

Costa tweeted his "deepest regret for the victims ... and a word of encouragement and strength for all who help combat this scourge."

"We are most likely facing the biggest tragedy of human life that we have known," he said.

There was no immediate identification of the victims. Portugal established a special diplomatic channel for embassies to receive information on foreign citizens who "may be affected" by the fire.

The European Union responded to a call for assistance by Portuguese authorities. As a result, Spain sent four firefighting aircrafts on Sunday. France was also sending three aircraft and Greece's prime minister also offered to send firefighting help.

Many world leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron, Pope Francis and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, expressed solidarity with Portugal. Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy tweeted that he is "overwhelmed by the tragedy at Pedrogao Grande. The Portuguese people can count on our solidarity, support and care." !@COPYRIGHT=© 2017 Osprey Media Group Inc. All rights reserved.

REDWING, Sask. _ Crews in Saskatchewan are working to get the upper hand on a forest fire that has forced one rural municipality to declare a state of emergency and levelled one home.

Steve Roberts with the Ministry of Environment said Tuesday that 105 firefighters were battling the three-square-kilometre blaze just north of Prince Albert.

''Men and equipment are working on the containment lines to prevent any future spread of the fire. We worked through the night to establish those lines, and we're working with heavy equipment and water tankers to establish those (Tuesday),'' said Roberts.

''We will monitor the fire as well through the peak of the day to see how it behaves.''

Roberts said the fire appeared less voracious Tuesday than it had a day earlier. But he warned flare-ups were expected as temperatures reached 29 C in Prince Albert.

''Whether we will achieve full containment, I'm not sure at this time.''

One home in the rural municipality of Buckland was destroyed, another 60 homes were threatened and residents were told to leave. The Canadian Red Cross set up an evacuation centre at the Redwing School.

Roberts couldn't say if more families would be told to flee.

Buckland has declared a state of emergency to qualify for provincial aid.

Investigators are still trying to determine how the fire started, although it's believed it began in the forest near a golf course.

B3Portugal forest fire death toll likely to rise; 'We are most likely facing the biggest tragedy of human life that we have known'Helena Alves And Armando FrancaThe Associated PressPEDROGAO GRANDE, Portugal -

A raging forest fire in central Portugal sent flames sweeping over roads, killing at least 61 people, many of them trapped in their cars as they tried to flee, officials said Sunday. The country's prime minister called it "the biggest tragedy" that Portugal has experienced in decades and declared three days of national mourning.

A huge wall of thick smoke and bright red flames towered over the top of trees in the forested Pedrogao Grande area some 150 kilometres northeast of Lisbon where a lightning strike was believed to have sparked the blaze Saturday. Investigators found a tree that was hit during a "dry thunderstorm," the head of the national judicial police told Portuguese media.

Dry thunderstorms are frequent when falling water evaporates before reaching the ground because of high temperatures. Portugal, like most southern European countries, is prone to forest fires in the dry summer months. At least four other significant wildfires affected different areas of the country on Sunday but the one in Pedrogao Grande was responsible for all the deaths.

"The dimensions of this fire have caused a human tragedy beyond any in our memory," said Prime Minister Antonio Costa told reporters on his arrival at the scene Sunday. "Something extraordinary has taken place and we have to wait for technicians to properly determine its causes."

He said the death toll was lowered from the previously reported 62 victims because one person had been counted twice. However, he added that "there's no point in feeling joyful for that, because surely we will find more victims as we progress." Police are searching charred areas of the forest and isolated homes for more bodies.

More than 350 soldiers on Sunday joined the 700 firefighters who have been struggling to put out the blaze. Authorities say temperatures as high as 40 degrees Celsius in the area in recent days might have also played a part in the inferno.

The forest fire deaths were the biggest in memory in Portugal, which saw 25 Portuguese soldiers die fighting wildfires in 1966. Last August, an outbreak of fires across Portugal killed four people, including three on the island of Madeira, and destroyed huge areas of forest.

Resident Isabel Brandao told The Associated Press that she had feared for her life when she saw the blaze.

"Yesterday we saw the fire but thought it was very far. I never thought it would come to this side," she said Sunday. "At 3:30 a.m., my mother-in-law woke me up quickly and we never went to sleep again. We were afraid the fire would reach us."

Other locals were also shocked. "This is a region that has had fires because of its forests, but we cannot remember a tragedy of these proportions," said Valdemar Alves, the mayor of Pedrogao Grande. "I am completely stunned by the number of deaths."

State broadcaster RTP showed terrifying images of several people on a road trying to escape the intense smoke that had reduced visibility to a few meters. A young man shared a bottle of water with a distraught woman as she stumbled down the road.

Interior Ministry official Jorge Gomes said firefighting crews were having difficulties battling the fire, which was "very intense" in at least two of its four fronts. He said authorities were worried about strong winds that could help spreading the blaze further.

Schools in the area were closed until further notice and outdoor fires were banned, authorities announced Sunday.

Gomes gave a grim description of the deaths to RTP. He said at least 30 people died inside their cars as they tried to flee between the towns of Figueiro dos Vinhos and Castanheira de Pera. He says 17 others died right outside their cars or by the road, 11 people died in the forest and two people died in a car accident related to the fire and information was missing on the other deaths.

Gomes says 54 people were also injured in the fire, 5 of them seriously, including four firefighters and a minor.

Costa tweeted his "deepest regret for the victims ... and a word of encouragement and strength for all who help combat this scourge."

"We are most likely facing the biggest tragedy of human life that we have known," he said.

There was no immediate identification of the victims. Portugal established a special diplomatic channel for embassies to receive information on foreign citizens who "may be affected" by the fire.

The European Union responded to a call for assistance by Portuguese authorities. As a result, Spain sent four firefighting aircrafts on Sunday. France was also sending three aircraft and Greece's prime minister also offered to send firefighting help.

Many world leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron, Pope Francis and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, expressed solidarity with Portugal. Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy tweeted that he is "overwhelmed by the tragedy at Pedrogao Grande. The Portuguese people can count on our solidarity, support and care." !@COPYRIGHT=© 2017 Osprey Media Group Inc. All rights reserved.

urn:contentItem:7YB8-W5W1-2R6R-51T5-00000-00Small forest fire under control near NW Ont. ghost town of Jackfish2010-04-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisQUEBEC-ONTARIO REGIONAL NEWSSmall forest fire under control near NW Ont. ghost town of JackfishCP

TERRACE BAY, Ont. _ It could be months before provincial investigators are in a position to say exactly what caused a small forest fire in the vicinity of a ghost town just east of Terrace Bay, Ont.

''We suspect it was human-caused, because there's been no lightning (in the last few days),'' Ministry of Natural Resources fire operations supervisor Rick Payne said Monday.

Payne said the fire around the former Jackfish townsite was ''being held'' Monday afternoon and was not expected to spread.

The fire, which was reported Sunday afternoon, grew to 10 hectares before it was battled by two waterbombers, five ranger crews, three helicopters and Terrace Bay's volunteer fire department.

Payne said two conservation officers and a ''fire behaviour specialist'' were at the scene Monday investigating.

Jackfish, once a fishing village where CPR trains picked up coal and water, hasn't been inhabited since the 1950s. Most buildings still standing are in ruins.

About a dozen cottages eight kilometres away at Jackfish Lake, visible from the Trans-Canada Highway, were not affected and no cottage residents had to be evacuated.

As of the weekend, there had been 121 forest fires and just over 500 hectares burned.

Last summer, damp and cool conditions resulted in only 15 fires and only 22 hectares burned across the province.

A provincial fire ban remains in place between the Manitoba border and Lake Nipigon.

MNR has 25 fire crews, one CL-215,<br/>one CL-415 water bomber and four helicopters working on Thunder Bay Fire 21.</p><p>The fire is putting up an 8,000-foot smoke column.</p><p>MNR has notified the 250 residents of the community of Gull Bay First<br/>Nation on the western shore of Lake Nipigon that they may have to be evacuated<br/>from the area because of the fire.</p><p>A Restricted Fire Zone (RFZ) for much of northwestern Ontario remains in<br/>effect from the Manitoba border east to Lake Nipigon, and north from the U.S.<br/>border to just north of Pickle Lake. The RFZ includes the city of Thunder Bay.</p><p>Under the RFZ regulation, all open fires are prohibited, including<br/>campfires. MNR asks the public to be careful when using a portable stove.<br/>People found guilty of violating the RFZ regulation are liable to a fine of up<br/>to $ 1,000 and could be assessed the costs of fire suppression.</p><p>The other main problem area today is near Timmins. A 48-hectare fire<br/>about eight kilometres from the town forced a brief evacuation of a trailer<br/>park yesterday afternoon. The residents of the park returned in the evening.<br/>MNR has five fire crews and several water bombers working on the fire, along<br/>with municipal fire crews.</p><p>In all, 23 forest fires are burning more than 4,500 hectares in<br/>northeastern and northwestern Ontario. To date there have been more than 240 forest<br/>fires in Ontario, burning about 6,000 hectares of forest.</p><p>Four of MNR's recently purchased CL-415 waterbombers are now in service,<br/>showing the foresight of the government's decision to buy them in time for the<br/>beginning of the fire season. urn:contentItem:7YB9-6DR1-2R6R-511W-00000-00Small forest fire under control near NW Ont. ghost town of Jackfish2010-04-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisQUEBEC-ONTARIO REGIONAL NEWSSmall forest fire under control near NW Ont. ghost town of JackfishCP

TERRACE BAY, Ont. _ It could be months before provincial investigators are in a position to say exactly what caused a small forest fire in the vicinity of a ghost town just east of Terrace Bay, Ont.

''We suspect it was human-caused, because there's been no lightning (in the last few days),'' Ministry of Natural Resources fire operations supervisor Rick Payne said Monday.

Payne said the fire around the former Jackfish townsite was ''being held'' Monday afternoon and was not expected to spread.

The fire, which was reported Sunday afternoon, grew to 10 hectares before it was battled by two waterbombers, five ranger crews, three helicopters and Terrace Bay's volunteer fire department.

Payne said two conservation officers and a ''fire behaviour specialist'' were at the scene Monday investigating.

Jackfish, once a fishing village where CPR trains picked up coal and water, hasn't been inhabited since the 1950s. Most buildings still standing are in ruins.

About a dozen cottages eight kilometres away at Jackfish Lake, visible from the Trans-Canada Highway, were not affected and no cottage residents had to be evacuated.

As of the weekend, there had been 121 forest fires and just over 500 hectares burned.

Last summer, damp and cool conditions resulted in only 15 fires and only 22 hectares burned across the province.

A provincial fire ban remains in place between the Manitoba border and Lake Nipigon.

(Thunder Bay Chronicle-Journal)

urn:contentItem:7YGS-8141-2R6R-508J-00000-00Forest fire north of Prince Albert forces 50 to 60 residents to flee2010-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSForest fire north of Prince Albert forces 50 to 60 residents to fleeCP

REDWING, Sask. _ Fifty to 60 people had to leave their homes due a forest fire burning north of Prince Albert, Sask.

Three fire departments _ Buckland, Shellbrook and Prince Albert _ were helping Saskatchewan Ministry of Environment battle the blaze in the hamlet of Redwing, about 10 kilometres north of Prince Albert.

Aircraft were dropping water and bright red fire retardant onto the burning ground.

The fire is believed to have started around 1 p.m. Monday in the Nisbet Forest.

Alex Paul, battalion chief with Prince Albert fire department, says there are a lot of homes in the line of the fire.

He says there's no water supply in those areas because there are no hydrants.

Residents evacuated from their homes live on the east side of Lempereur Road in the community of Redwing.

Paul Fortier and his wife Estelle, residents of the area for 23 years, sat in their car and watched the thick, grey clouds of smoke billowing high in the sky.

''They told us not to go (closer), so we didn't,'' Paul said.

The couple's home was among those in the path of the fire, but they stayed optimistic.

''As long as there are no people (there), a house and everything can be replaced,'' he said.

It's not known how the fire started.

(Prince Albert Daily Herald)

urn:contentItem:52W6-1V61-F03B-W3GV-00000-00Forest Fire Burning In Slave Lake Area2011-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisForest Fire Burning In Slave Lake AreaBy Richard Macedo/Reuters

Oil and gas companies operating in the Slave Lake area of northwest Alberta are assessing the impact of a firestorm that swept through the area Sunday.

Police say nearly one-third of the town of 7,000 has been destroyed or damaged, although media reports say there are no reports of deaths or injuries. Residents were ordered to leave Sunday afternoon and many have settled at evacuation centres in other northern Alberta communities, including Edmonton.

"We are assessing this morning," said Graham White, a spokesperson for Husky Energy Inc. "Our interests are primarily to the north and east of the town site."

Husky has production from more than 50 oil and gas pools in the Rainbow area covering approximately 1,300 square kilometres. The company has a 50 per cent interest in and operates the Rainbow Lake processing plant.

Clean-up operations at the site of an oil spill on Plains Midstream Canada's Rainbow Pipeline have been suspended due to the forest fire threat, the company said in an update.

"Plains has been instructed to evacuate onsite staff," the company stated. "Clean-up operations will resume once the evacuation order is lifted and it is determined safe to do so. The safety of our workers remains our primary concern."

The portion of the 187,000 bbl a-day Rainbow pipeline owned by Plains All American Pipeline LP that had remained open following the spill was shut on Sunday because of the threat of forest fires.

Plains said the portion of the line that ran from its Nipisi terminal to Edmonton, Alberta, was closed due to the threat of fire. That portion of Rainbow was last said to carry about half the line's capacity.

The Alberta government continues to work closely with local municipal officials and agencies to ensure the safety of residents evacuated from the Slave Lake wildfire. Travel in and around Slave Lake is restricted. Road and highway closures in effect are: highway two between highways 33 and 44, highway eight between highways two and 986, and highway 15 between highways 88 and 679.

Approximately 90 per cent of the residents have been safely evacuated, according to the province. Only essential or firefighter staff remain in the town of Slave Lake. The 40 local firefighters from the Slave Lake Fire Department are being assisted by more than 120 firefighters from Alberta cities.

Canada Task Force 2 (CAN-TF2), a national heavy urban search and rescue team has been deployed to Westlock to assist the situation in Slave Lake. CAN-TF2 is one of five heavy urban search and rescue teams in Canada. Canada Task Force 2 is a partnership between City of Calgary, Public Safety Canada, Alberta Emergency Management Agency, Alberta Health Services, STARS and numerous other agencies throughout Alberta.

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (11:55 p.m., Thursday, July 26): By the evening of Thursday, July 26, there were 45 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held, under control or being observed.

River Valley Fire Cluster

The River Valley Fire Cluster includes two fires: North Bay 62 and North Bay 42. Both fires are now being held, meaning that the fires are not expected to spread under current conditions. The ministry is continuing to monitor North Bay 25 to the west of the cluster, which is now under control.

There are 154 people working on these fires including firefighters from Ontario, British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Nova Scotia and Mexico.

Crews took advantage of the cooler, dry day to make solid progress on all fires. On North Bay 42, crews continued to secure the perimeter on the north side as well as working on hot spots on the west side. For North Bay 62, crews continued to work the perimeter of the fire while some crews began to recover equipment from the fire.

Crews completed removal of sprinkler protection from all structures.

Temagami Fire Cluster:

Fire activity has proven more manageable on fires in the Temagami cluster with all active fires in this cluster now classified as either being held or under control.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster:

North Bay 72 remains at 27,579 hectares and is listed as not under control. However, the overcast skies and wet weather of late has allowed firefighters to consolidate hose lines along the perimeter. While there is much work still to be done, progress is being made daily.

Front line staff continue to work with heavy equipment operators to establish dozer guards in areas where this type of suppression is suitable. This goes a long way to secure the perimeter of the fire.

The Incident Management Team continues to observe North Bay 18, 19, 46, 59 and 61. While these fires have been quiet, they are not considered out.

Currently there are 10 helicopters assigned to this cluster. Transitioning of staff is ongoing as personnel depart for their home locations and new staff arrive. Crews arrived from northwestern Ontario today and more are expected from Saskatchewan tomorrow.

The ministry continues to have firefighters from British Columbia, Alberta, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, Northwest Territories and Mexico work on this cluster. Restricted Fire Zone expanded

urn:contentItem:7YSW-WN71-2R6R-54GC-00000-00200 people feeling the heat, opt to leave homes in face of Manitoba forest fire2010-06-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWS200 people feeling the heat, opt to leave homes in face of Manitoba forest fireCP

CRANBERRY PORTAGE, Man. _ Despite a thick smoky haze hanging in the sky from a forest fire raging only kilometres away, some residents in Cranberry Portage, Man., remain vigilant in staying even as others are desperately evacuating.

Dennis Head plans on staying and saving his house, if he can, even though his wife and family have left the community and headed to The Pas.

''(My wife) was afraid that it would come in and burn everything up,'' Head said Thursday afternoon. ''But I still have a house to protect.''

A voluntary evactuation was put in place in Cranberry Portage as a sprawling, 100-square-kilometre fire at Kisseynew Lake burns out of control because of extremely dry conditions, low humidity and strong, gusting winds.

The province is fighting the inferno with 29 firefighting crews, 11 helicopters and eight water bombers. Fire crews from Ontario and Minnesota are also helping.

And while the haze still stretches for hundreds of kilometres, covering most of northeastern Manitoba, the weather on Thursday was allowing the town reeve to breath a little easier.

''The weather helped us quite a bit,'' Larry Johnson said. ''The evacuation notice remains voluntary.''

In all, about 200 of the town's 650 residents have left.

Another 200 students at the Frontier Collegiate have been sent home. As well, he said, the approximately 300 tourists in the area have left.

Johnson said people are being asked to register at an evacuation office at the University College of the North.

''My family has left,'' Johnson said. ''I'm here until I have to leave. I'm on the front lines.''

The fire forced a half-dozen people to flee from nearby Cormorant, 80 km northeast of The Pas, Wednesday afternoon.

The campgrounds in the Grass River Provincial Park were under mandatory evacuation.

''Winds have been pushing (the fire) one way, then back another way and then another way,'' said Gary Friesen, manager of Manitoba's forest fire program. ''It has been so constant, it's like a wall that's up there.''

Rain is expected in the region on Saturday, Friesen said, but it's unknown how much there will be.

(Winnipeg Free Press)

REDWING, Sask. _ Fifty to 60 people had to leave their homes due a forest fire burning north of Prince Albert, Sask.

WOLLASTON LAKE, Sask. - At least one military plane has landed at Wollaston Lake, Saskatchewan, to evacuate people from two northern communities threatened by wildfires.

Public Safety Minister Vic Toews (TAVES) and National Defence Minister Peter MacKay said late yesterday that Canadian Forces search and rescue aircraft will evacuate 400 residents from Wollaston Lake and Hatchet Lake First Nation.

Smoke and shifting winds were hampering efforts to evacuate the community, which is 840 kilometres north of Saskatoon and accessible only by air.

The five-square-kilometre fire was burning next to the airport and winds were blowing smoke across the runway, shutting down access to the facility earlier yesterday.

Saskatchewan officials said late yesterday the airport and road were reopened and another 388 residents were evacuated.

About 240 got out on Tuesday.

That left 400 hunkered down in the community's schools.

Three C-C-130 Hercules aircraft and four C-H-146 Griffon helicopters were expected to arrive before midnight local time last night, and one C-C-130J Hercules was to be deployed early today.

Emergency officials in Saskatchewan say each Hercules can carry up to 96 passengers, while a Griffon can take six to 10.

The fire was first reported Monday and the evacuation order came down Tuesday.

An official says the fire was likely human-caused because there haven't been any lightning strikes in the area.

(CP) _ Residents were again told Friday to be ready to flee their homes with just an hour's notice Friday due to smoke blowing from a forest fire near their small northern Manitoba community.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>The fire has grown to 11 square kilometres and jumped the Limestone River north of Bird on the rail line going north to Churchill, said Manitoba Conservation in a news release.</p><p>A team of 55 firefighters was working to keep it away from the community, using three helicopters, two water bombers and three bulldozers.</p><p>The release said sprinkler systems have been placed around homes in the town of 150 people, which is 800 kilometres north of Winnipeg.</p><p>Measures were also taken to protect Manitoba Hydro's facilities on the Limestone River.</p><p>Residents in nearby Fox Lake First were also put on one-hour evacuation notice.</p><p>Chief George Neepin said residents were nervous, adding buses and helicopters were standing by to bring people to nearby Gillam or Churchill.</p><p>The fire came to within one kilometre of Bird on Thursday, then the winds shifted and pushed the fire away from the community.</p><p>Officials still don't know what caused the fire. There have been 76 fires recorded this spring, compared to 69 last year.</p><p>Manitoba Conservation said many of the recent fires appear to have been started by humans.</p><p>The department has laid three charges and issued three warnings under the Wildfires Act. Those found responsible can be billed the costs of extinguishing the fire.</p><p>Fire officials advise people to be careful when burning outdoors as a few warm and windy days can spark the right conditions for a forest fire.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier CRANBERRY PORTAGE, Man. _ Despite a thick smoky haze hanging in the sky from a forest fire raging only kilometres away, some residents in Cranberry Portage, Man., remain vigilant in staying even as others are desperately evacuating.

Dennis Head plans on staying and saving his house, if he can, even though his wife and family have left the community and headed to The Pas.

''(My wife) was afraid that it would come in and burn everything up,'' Head said Thursday afternoon. ''But I still have a house to protect.''

A voluntary evactuation was put in place in Cranberry Portage as a sprawling, 100-square-kilometre fire at Kisseynew Lake burns out of control because of extremely dry conditions, low humidity and strong, gusting winds.

The province is fighting the inferno with 29 firefighting crews, 11 helicopters and eight water bombers. Fire crews from Ontario and Minnesota are also helping.

And while the haze still stretches for hundreds of kilometres, covering most of northeastern Manitoba, the weather on Thursday was allowing the town reeve to breath a little easier.

''The weather helped us quite a bit,'' Larry Johnson said. ''The evacuation notice remains voluntary.''

In all, about 200 of the town's 650 residents have left.

Another 200 students at the Frontier Collegiate have been sent home. As well, he said, the approximately 300 tourists in the area have left.

Johnson said people are being asked to register at an evacuation office at the University College of the North.

''My family has left,'' Johnson said. ''I'm here until I have to leave. I'm on the front lines.''

The fire forced a half-dozen people to flee from nearby Cormorant, 80 km northeast of The Pas, Wednesday afternoon.

The campgrounds in the Grass River Provincial Park were under mandatory evacuation.

''Winds have been pushing (the fire) one way, then back another way and then another way,'' said Gary Friesen, manager of Manitoba's forest fire program. ''It has been so constant, it's like a wall that's up there.''

Rain is expected in the region on Saturday, Friesen said, but it's unknown how much there will be.

(Winnipeg Free Press)

The Fund hopes to raise more than $1 million in donations to provide relief and support for victims of the forest fire tragedy.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"7-Eleven is donating $10,000 immediately to the Red Cross Fire Fund to help support those unfortunately affected by the forest fires," said 7-Eleven Canada Senior Vice President David Huey. "In addition, we will accept donations through each of our Canadian stores in the hope that this will make it easy for the many Canadians who want to help those affected by this disaster."</p><p>For two months, donations will be accepted in special collection containers at 490 7-Eleven Canada stores from BC to Ontario. Donations to the Red Cross B.C. Forest Fire Response Fund can also be made by calling 1-800-418-1111 or on the Internet at <url normalizedValue="https://secure.csfm.com/redcross/">https://secure.csfm.com/redcross/</url>. </p><p>7-Eleven managers and employees in Kelowna have been strongly affected by the forest fires as well, according to Ian Cook, Market Manager, Interior BC for 7-Eleven Canada. "Our staff have been working 16-hour days to keep stores open to provide workers with food and basic supplies," Cook said. "Nine employees have insisted on working daily despite being subject to fire evacuation notices of their own."</p><p>Kelowna's Lakeshore Drive 7-Eleven store was evacuated with 15 minutes notice and closed for two days last week due to the fire. The Rutland store nearby has remained on one-hour evacuation alert for the past week, pending weather conditions and fire movements.</p><p>"The scale and impact of this fire is hard to imagine and we join the community in thanking the firefighters, RCMP, equipment operators, hospital and ambulance personnel who have worked so hard to fight the fire," Cook added.</p><p>Cook said business at the two stores nearest the blaze dropped somewhat because more than 20,000 residents were evacuated away from the path of the fire. Stores remain open and products such as batteries, water and basic food items have been in demand by fire workers and those residents able to remain in their homes.</p><p>As a resident, Cook said he could hardly believe the miles of burned landscape visible near the city. Though the community is doing its best to cope with the impact of the forest fire, he hopes Canadians will support the Red Cross Fund in a big way.</p><p>7-Eleven, Inc. is the premier name and largest chain in the convenience retailing industry with 25,000 stores. Additional money can be taken out of an emergency fire fund if necessary.</p><p>"If the fire stays this bad, we'll have the resources there to fight it," Hodgson said.</p><p>Battling last year's forest fires cost the government $110 million, well over its $18 million budget.</p><p>Since lightning struck last week, about 400 fires have claimed more than 2,000 square kilometres of forest.</p><p>Manitoba, Quebec and New Brunswick have also been battling forest blazes.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) - Firefighters in the northern Ontario city of Timmins remained on alert Saturday, on the watch for spot fires that could flare into a second forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true">About 400 area residents were permitted to return home Friday after a fire that threatened to engulf the city was brought under control.</p><p>A state of emergency will remain in effect until officials with the Ministry of Natural Resources can confirm the threat of a second fire is over, Timmins fire chief Lester Cudmore said.</p><p>"We're very concerned about the dry conditions,'' he said.</p><p>"You've got to remember, when you're dealing with forest fires a spot fire can turn into a forest fire within an hour.''</p><p>Cudmore said small fires continue to burn in the bush, but there is no immediate threat to Timmins.</p><p>Thurday's fire, burning along a 200-hectare stretch and fed by high winds, jumped the 120-metre-wide Mattagami River and a highway.</p><p>No serious injuries were reported, but the flames destroyed hydro poles and a few sheds.</p><p>Sixteen fire crews were at the scene, along two water bombers, two bulldozers and two helicopters.</p><p>About 400 people from two trailer parks west of the city and residents from around Baker Lake and the Mattagami River were evacuated Thursday.</p><p>They were allowed to return to their homes Friday, but were asked to stay near their properties and away from the fire.</p><p>The cause of the blaze is under investigation.</p><p>Meanwhile, the forest fire hazard was rated as extreme across the Dryden, Kenora and Fort Frances districts because of the warm, dry weather.</p><p>A fire on an island in Wabigoon Lake destroyed a sauna Friday night and five new fires were spotted in the Nipigon district and one in the Thunder Bay (CP) _ A forest fire north of Merritt was under control Thursday as fire crews were scaled back and their efforts turned to mopping up and patrolling the area.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The 1.5 square kilometre fire about two kilometres from Merritt in southern B.C. began after a car crashed into a ditch last Saturday and ignited on the Coquihalla Highway.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Fire information officer Shelly Marsh said the weather in the province was ripe for more fires as she warned campers to be careful in the forests.</p><p>The Coastal Fire Centre in Parksville issued a ban on category one open fires, including campfires, in select areas on the south coast of B.C. on Thursday.</p><p>Affected areas include Vancouver Island south of Campbell River; all Georgia Strait islands south of Hernando Island, including the southern Gulf islands and the Howe Sound islands; and the Chilliwack and Squamish forest fire districts.</p><p>Category one fires are defined as those that burn piled material less than one metre high and one metre wide.</p><p>Meanwhile, a fire at Sleetsis Creek south of Spences Bridge was still active on Thursday.</p><p>B.C. Forest Service spokeswoman Donna MacPherson said the blaze had grown slightly to more than 33.6 square kilometres, sending thick smoke over the communities of Spences Bridge, Lytton and Boston Bar.</p><p>"Unfortunately the local folks are going to have smoke to contend with and this may continue until about Sunday,'' she said.</p><p>The cause of the fire, which was discovered last Friday, was under investigation.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20050804CPCPD6336</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2005</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4GT5-21D0-01G6-933H-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="248"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2005 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="04" month="08" year="2005"><dateText>August 4, 2005 Thursday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="company"><classificationItem score="73"><className>B C FOREST SERVICE </className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>ENVIRONMENT; urn:contentItem:4P12-HB90-TX4V-K1WC-00000-00Air tankers fighting forest fire 450 kilometres northwest of Whitehorse2007-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSAir tankers fighting forest fire 450 kilometres northwest of WhitehorseCHUCK TOBINCP

WHITEHORSE (CP) _ A forest fire burning northeast of Beaver Creek, Yukon, has jumped up to alert status for the territory's Wildland Fire Management branch.

Air tankers were on the lightning-caused fire about 450 kilometres northwest of Whitehorse for several hours Monday.

They were working it again Tuesday, along with 10 firefighters on three initial attack crews from Haines Junction and Dawson City.

Fire spokesman George Maratos said Tuesday the Beaver Creek fire and five other new lightning starts have prompted fire management staff to look at what additional resources are available in British Columbia and Alaska, if required.

The Beaver Creek fire remains the priority because of its 75-hectare size and its proximity to the western Yukon community of 110 residents, he said.

Maratos said Beaver Creek is not threatened although the Emergency Measures Organization has been notified.

The fire is burning in a northerly direction away from Beaver Creek.

Maratos said the low fire danger rating for the Beaver Creek area is working in the firefighters' favour.

But there is a warming trend sweeping across the entire territory with the expectation of more lightning.

Maratos said aircraft detection flights are being deployed to look for any new fires caused by the recent spate of lightning across different areas of the territory.

(Alta-Fires)</p><p>In Alberta, 16-hundred firefighters are battling 21 forest fires, but only three are out of control.</p><p>A 78-thousand hectare blaze south of Fort McMurray hasn't moved for several days.</p><p>In the northwest, a 64-thousand-hectare fire near Foggy Mountain and one about half that size near Melvin Creek are also holding. urn:contentItem:5X05-5GJ1-F103-34HD-00000-00Nakusp mayor says logging truck fire shows need to review rules2019-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisNEWSNakusp mayor says logging truck fire shows need to review rules

The mayor of Nakusp is calling for better co-operation between government departments after a logging truck caught fire on the highway north of the village on Aug. 22, sparking a forest fire that burned for days.

Tom Zeleznik says the fire got progressively worse while several groups of responders figured out who could tackle it.

"It's very frustrating," he says. "Here you have local resources able to tackle a fire like this, they have the training, but because of jurisdiction and liability, they can't. Their hands are tied."

Zeleznik, who's also a member of the local volunteer fire department, was one of the first people on the scene of the fire, near the Halfway River.

A logging truck's load started smouldering as it pulled onto the highway. After trying to douse the logs with an extinguisher, the driver called in to his head office.

"The fellow did everything correctly," says Zeleznik. "He found a safe place to park, where people could get by him, he then called for help."

The logging company contacted 911 and reported the problem.

Hours to respond

Zeleznik kept a diary of the chain of events that shows it took three hours from the first call by the driver until the fire was tackled by local volunteer firefighters - and another hour after that before the BC Wildfire Service began fighting the forest fire it caused.

That's because the truck picked an inconvenient place to burn: it was outside the Nakusp Fire Department's area, neither the logging company nor the local highways branch crews could fight it, and BC Wildfire Service crews don't fight vehicle or structural fires.

Zeleznik's log shows the fire was first reported just after 2 p.m. on Friday. He arrived about an hour later to help, in his capacity as a volunteer firefighter.

"[I] was informed that our local Nakusp Volunteer Fire Department could not help as it was out of their jurisdiction," his notes state. "[I] was also informed at the scene the Southeast Fire Centre could do nothing until the fire moved into the surrounding bush/forest... [it was] stated fires on the highway [are the highways department] jurisdiction."

Zeleznik's further notes show that after receiving the okay from RCMP, he went back to a nearby scale/dump yard to pick up a loader that could remove the smouldering logs from the truck. When he got back with the machine, about an hour later, the Nakusp Volunteer Fire Department truck and crew had arrived, having just "been given permission by authorities to respond outside their jurisdiction to this scene."

"When they got out there, they fought hard," says Zeleznik. "They really helped out immensely, but they couldn't put the fire out without a loader there to help rip the load apart. They soaked it down, but they couldn't get down inside the load."

That was about 5 p.m. - three hours after the first call came in - and the fire began spreading to the surrounding forest.

Zeleznik's log shows that at 6:30 p.m. "helicopter and water bombers arrive to fight the forest fire ... Forest fire is now well into the forest, with rocks falling onto the highway."

A spokesperson for the Southeast Fire Centre says they had an assessment officer on the scene within 15 minutes of receiving a call, at about 3 p.m. Ashley Davidoff says that person immediately called in an initial attack team and aerial support to tackle the fire.

Davidoff says the initial attack or aerial crews do not suppress vehicle fires, but they did deal with the situation by the book.

"It was under control in the first operational period. In regards to initial attack success on a wildfire, it was very successful, " says Davidoff. "That's what we aim for. After the initial assessment, crews were launched."

Aviation resources were called in, but it can take a while for the crews to gear up and get airborne.

Filling the gap in service

Zeleznik says bureaucratic delays made the situation worse.

"It sort of fell between the cracks, in my opinion," says Zeleznik. "We have the resources. All our local fire department crew are trained, logging company crews are trained in firefighting, and highways road-building crews are trained. They're well versed in all those procedures.

"If you look at the pictures, at the start it is just white smoke. White smoke isn't going to start a forest fire. And you could have easily doused it down then. In hindsight a lot of things could have happened with this one."

Though he understands issues like liability and safety have to be paramount, "we're just asking for local resources to be able to be used in situations like this," he says.

Zeleznik says he's spoken to officials in several provincial departments about the problem.

"It pretty well has to start at the top, go to Victoria, and say we really have to look at this crack, this break in the service," he says. "Maybe this is a good eye-opener for everybody."

Zeleznik hopes fire officials from various departments will review this incident to see how it could have been handled more effectively.

"What you do is learn from your mistakes and prevent it from happening again," he says. "Everyone is worried about liability, risk, and if you are trained enough, or are you going to get sued. The days of just 'getting it done' are kind of gone now.

"It's kind of sad how far we have gone."

The fire ended up closing Highway 23 for several hours, and reduced traffic to single-lane alternating the next day.

At press time, the fire was still listed as being 0.6 hectares in size, and was considered "under control." Fire crews were monitoring for hot spots.

The truck cab was saved, but the trailer was heavily damaged by the fire.

urn:contentItem:5P0R-DNM1-DY9S-T22B-00000-00New online map shows wildfire risk across Newfoundland and Labrador2017-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisNATIONAL,ATLANTICNew online map shows wildfire risk across Newfoundland and LabradorNew online map shows wildfire risk in N.L.The Canadian Press

ST. JOHN'S, N.L. - As firefighters on Canada's west coast battle wildfires sweeping through the British Columbia Interior, the country's eastern-most province is hoping a new tool will help stomp out forest fires before they start.

Newfoundland and Labrador released an online forest fire hazard map Tuesday that provides real-time information about the risk of wildfires throughout the province.

The risk ratings range from low to extreme, and are colour-coded from blue to red. The provincial map is broken down into 23 fire management zones, which are assessed using data from weather stations.

The fire hazard is a relative rating of how easy it is to ignite forest vegetation, how fast a fire may spread and how difficult a fire may be to control.

Land Resources Minister Steve Crocker said the online map will make the province's emergency response teams more efficient.

"The ability to access forest fire hazard data in a timely fashion provides forest managers with a valuable tool to monitor wildfire potential," he said in a statement. "This new online service also gives residents, who are either engaging in forest-related activities or planning to visit various regions of the province, prompt access to important weather and safety information."

Newfoundland burn permits issued during forest fire season are no longer valid when a high, very high or extreme fire hazard rating exists, Land Resources spokesman Craig Renouf said.

New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island each have some version of an online forest fire weather index.

New Brunswick's online map indicates weather burning is open, restricted or closed, using green, yellow or red to colour-code the burn index.

Nova Scotia has a similar online map, which indicates whether it's a "burn day," "restricted burn day" or "non-burn day." During wildfire risk season from mid-March to mid-October, all domestic brush burning and campfires must adhere to daily burning restrictions in the province.

P.E.I. has an online gauge for each region of the province, which indicates the latest forest fire weather rating.

urn:contentItem:5WXW-B1D1-JDH1-C35D-00000-00Nakusp mayor says logging truck fire shows need to review rules2019-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisNEWSNakusp mayor says logging truck fire shows need to review rules

The mayor of Nakusp is calling for better co-operation between government departments after a logging truck caught fire on the highway north of the village last Thursday, sparking a forest fire that burned for days.

Tom Zeleznik says the fire got progressively worse while several groups of responders figured out who could tackle it.

"It's very frustrating," he says. "Here you have local resources able to tackle a fire like this, they have the training, but because of jurisdiction and liability, they can't. Their hands are tied."

Zeleznik, who's also a member of the local volunteer fire department, was one of the first people on the scene of the fire, near the Halfway River.

A logging truck's load started smouldering as it pulled onto the highway. After trying to douse the logs with an extinguisher, the driver called in to his head office.

"The fellow did everything correctly," says Zeleznik. "He found a safe place to park, where people could get by him, he then called for help."

The logging company contacted 911 and reported the problem.

Hours to respond

Zeleznik kept a diary of the chain of events that shows it took three hours from the first call by the driver until the fire was tackled by local volunteer firefighters - and another hour after that before the BC Wildfire Service began fighting the forest fire it caused.

That's because the truck picked an inconvenient place to burn: it was outside the Nakusp Fire Department's area, neither the logging company nor the local highways branch crews could fight it, and BC Wildfire Service crews don't fight vehicle or structural fires.

Zeleznik's log shows the fire was first reported just after 2 p.m. on Friday. He arrived about an hour later to help, in his capacity as a volunteer firefighter.

"[I] was informed that our local Nakusp Volunteer Fire Department could not help as it was out of their jurisdiction," his notes state. "[I] was also informed at the scene the Southeast Fire Centre could do nothing until the fire moved into the surrounding bush/forest... [it was] stated fires on the highway [are the highways department] jurisdiction."

Zeleznik's further notes show that after receiving the okay from RCMP, he went back to a nearby scale/dump yard to pick up a loader that could remove the smouldering logs from the truck. When he got back with the machine, about an hour later, the Nakusp Volunteer Fire Department truck and crew had arrived, having just "been given permission by authorities to respond outside their jurisdiction to this scene."

"When they got out there, they fought hard," says Zeleznik. "They really helped out immensely, but they couldn't put the fire out without a loader there to help rip the load apart. They soaked it down, but they couldn't get down inside the load."

That was about 5 p.m. - three hours after the first call came in - and the fire began spreading to the surrounding forest.

Zeleznik's log shows that at 6:30 p.m. "helicopter and water bombers arrive to fight the forest fire ... Forest fire is now well into the forest, with rocks falling onto the highway."

A spokesperson for the Southeast Fire Centre says they had an assessment officer on the scene within 15 minutes of receiving a call, at about 3 p.m. Ashley Davidoff says that person immediately called in an initial attack team and aerial support to tackle the fire.

Davidoff says the initial attack or aerial crews do not suppress vehicle fires, but they did deal with the situation by the book.

"It was under control in the first operational period. In regards to initial attack success on a wildfire, it was very successful, " says Davidoff. "That's what we aim for. After the initial assessment, crews were launched."

Aviation resources were called in, but it can take a while for the crews to gear up and get airborne.

Filling the gap in service

Zeleznik says bureaucratic delays made the situation worse.

"It sort of fell between the cracks, in my opinion," says Zeleznik. "We have the resources. All our local fire department crew are trained, logging company crews are trained in firefighting, and highways road-building crews are trained. They're well versed in all those procedures.

"If you look at the pictures, at the start it is just white smoke. White smoke isn't going to start a forest fire. And you could have easily doused it down then. In hindsight a lot of things could have happened with this one."

Though he understands issues like liability and safety have to be paramount, "we're just asking for local resources to be able to be used in situations like this," he says.

Zeleznik says he's spoken to officials in several provincial departments about the problem.

"It pretty well has to start at the top, go to Victoria, and say we really have to look at this crack, this break in the service," he says. "Maybe this is a good eye-opener for everybody."

Zeleznik hopes fire officials from various departments will review this incident to see how it could have been handled more effectively.

"What you do is learn from your mistakes and prevent it from happening again," he says. "Everyone is worried about liability, risk, and if you are trained enough, or are you going to get sued. The days of just 'getting it done' are kind of gone now.

"It's kind of sad how far we have gone."

The fire ended up closing Highway 23 for several hours last Thursday, and reduced traffic to single-lane alternating the next day.

At press time, the fire was still listed as being 0.6 hectares in size, and was considered "under control." Fire crews were monitoring for hot spots.

The truck cab was saved, but the trailer was heavily damaged by the fire.

urn:contentItem:5P37-F0S1-F105-61YX-00000-00Forest fire like a raging river2017-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisNEWSForest fire like a raging riverPhil Melnychuk

During the height of the Williams Lake wildfires last week, Susan Heard had been in constant contact with her daughter Tegan Heard, a Maple Ridge native, now living west just of Williams Lake.

They'd talk three times a day, either by phone or Facebook, just to make sure everthing was OK, until late last week.

"Then we heard nothing," said Susan.

Phone lines had been cut by the fire and there was no way to see if her daughter and her husband were safe.

Fortunately, there was a nearby school that had Internet and messages got out, saying that the couple was OK after fires ripped through the area.

The wildfire that tore around Tegan's house sounded like a torrential, raging, rushing river.

It got started July 8 and reached less than a kilometre from her home in Riske Creek, 60 kilometres west of Williams Lake.

"When you can hear the fire rolling down the valley at your neighbours' houses, it is scary. You could hear the fire coming and could see the smoke rolling straight at you. That was scary," Tegan said by e-mail Thursday.

At one point, the fire was just on the other side of the highway and if it had crossed the road, her house would have been gone. "My husband and other community members prevented that from happening."

Tegan was born and raised in Maple Ridge but has been up in Interior the last seven years working in Williams Lake.

When the evacuation order for Williams Lake came on July 15, the city emptied but about 90 people in the Riske Creek area, stayed and worked behind the fire lines to save their homes. Loggers and ranchers used their bulldozers, skidders ( a logging vehicle) and excavators to make fire breaks. They ran hoses to pump water, dug by hand and cut trees in a frantic effort to stop the fires. A local resident even jumped into his logging helicopter to direct crews below.

Tegan and her husband have an acreage with three horses, a dozen chickens, two dogs and a cat. While they fought the wildfire, they had also hatched an escape plan, with vehicles at the ready, if it got too dangerous.

"Thankfully, many people appreciate what we are doing to save our community. EB Horseman raises $6,000 for our community and delivered supplies to us today," she said.

With the couple still behind evacuation lines, getting supplies at first wasn't easy. All of the donations for essentials are distributed at evacuation centres in urban areas. However, now they have permission to go into town for supplies.

"Those guys have grit and determination," said Susan. "They stayed and fought it because if they hadn't, they would have lost it all.

"It's been quite an experience for them. I have to say, we're incredibly proud of them. They stuck to their guns. They had an escape plan if they had to get out. They weren't being foolish or risk taking, other than the obvious risks."

Susan said it was heartening one day to hear of a truckload of supplies roll in to Williams Lake from Ft. McMurray, Alta., which was hit by a wildfire last year.

While the fire has calmed down, residents still have their guards up. "This is in no way a done deal," said Susan.

According to BC Wildfire Service last week, the Hanceville-Riske Creek fire erupted July 8 and there were 145 firefighters on the blaze, supported by 14 helicopters.

Heard said her house and property is already fire resistant. The couple have removed thick brush from near the house and the grass is kept short. But they may remove a few more trees and set up an outdoor sprinkler system for the house and shop.

urn:contentItem:5JTC-N0D1-JBVR-31DD-00000-00B.C. premier says climate change is sparking need for national forest fire plan2016-05-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisNATIONALB.C. premier says climate change is sparking need for national forest fire planB.C. premier calls for national fire strategyBruce CheadleThe Canadian Press

OTTAWA - Climate change is leading to more wildfires and the country needs a national forest firefighting strategy, says B.C. Premier Christy Clark.

While the country has been transfixed by the raging fires around Fort McMurray in northern Alberta, British Columbia's interior is experiencing similar fire conditions this spring that have received far less attention.

"The federal government has to help us to come together and come up with a national forest fire-fighting strategy," Clark said in an interview with The Canadian Press.

"We've got a lot of experience with this in British Columbia."

The labour-intensive job of clearing flammable debris on the forest floor is just one aspect of controlling wildfires, she said, as is pooling national fire-fighting resources among provinces to attack the country's hot spots.

"That has begun," said Clark, adding more needs to be done "especially in terms of predictive work on where the fires will likely be."

About 80 wildfires are currently burning in B.C., many of them east of the Rocky Mountains and essentially part of the same boreal forest conditions that have consumed hundreds of thousands of hectares around Fort McMurray, forced the evacuation of more than 80,000 people and disrupted about a million barrels a day of oilsands production.

Because of the oilsands link, talk of climate change as a contributing factor in the Alberta wildfires has proven to be politically toxic - even though scientists have been predicting and tracking increased fire losses due to global warming for more than two decades.

Clark said dry forests and longer fire seasons mean the problem of fire damage is only going to get worse. This year's B.C. fire season was the earliest on record, she said.

"I make no secret, I tell people every day, one of the reasons we have so many terrible fires annually now - and almost every year is worse than the last - is because our climate is drying and our climate is drying because of climate change," said the B.C. premier.

"It's urgent that we fight climate change and do everything we can to beat it, because this isn't going to get better. Fires are going to get worse and it's happening all over North America."

British Columbia, said Clark, is "girding for what's going to come next."

The B.C. government has not yet needed to call for federal military assistance to fight the fires this year, as happened in Fort McMurray, but Clark said it continues to monitor the situation closely.

urn:contentItem:5W2S-MM81-JDH1-C4CW-00000-00Commentary: Keeping yourself and your family safe in an emergency2019-05-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisOPINIONCommentary: Keeping yourself and your family safe in an emergency

Ione Christensen

This is a good week to think about preparing for an emergency. There is a very low snowpack and we've had dry weather for two months. The forecast now calls for very warm, dry weather until the middle of May.

That means that a large forest fire is the most likely emergency that we should be preparing for in Whitehorse and other Yukon communities.

Do you have an emergency kit packed with everything that you will need for up to 72 hours? An emergency kit should contain a battery or windup radio, first aid kit, flashlight, water, food, pocket knife, cash and other essentials. Check the City of Whitehorse website for a complete list of what you should have or buy a ready-made kit at one of the local stores.

Do you have a family plan to prepare for or react to an emergency? If you have children in school make sure that you know where to pick them up. Have an alternate meeting place for other family members in case you can't go home.

You may not be able to communicate by phone, so know your plan. Make sure it includes your pets. Ensure that you have cash ready to purchase gas or other supplies, as credit cards may not work.

Make sure that medications, personal papers and passports are easily accessible. Consider the possibility of mobility problems for family members. Save important computer files on a hard drive or on 'the cloud'. Keep your gas tank full. Be aware of possible destinations near lakes and rivers, where you can plan to stay for a few days, or longer.

Forest fire disasters in Telegraph Creek, Fort McMurray and elsewhere in California and British Columbia over the last three years have prompted our governments to take action on emergency planning.

As a result there will be an emergency preparedness and evacuation exercise in collaboration with the Federal government.

Operation Nanook will take place in late May and the beginning of June. Hopefully that exercise will ensure that emergency plans will be available for all communities in the near future. Ask your MLA and city council to make it a priority.

The local and territorial governments will manage the big picture during an emergency, through the Emergency Measures Organization. (EMO). But you know what you need and where it is.

A battery radio is a must to help keep you informed of what is happening and where you should be going. Your property must be well prepared. Fire fighters will be fighting the big fire and individual homes will be a second priority. If you have done your job, there will not be a problem. Read up on emergency planning and be prepared.

Planning for a forest fire emergency should also include prevention. Being firesmart is the number one method to protect your home from a forest fire.

Remove big trees, shrubs and dry grass that are within 10 metres of your house. Remove flammables from under steps and decks.

Clear debris from your eaves troughs (rain gutters). The big spruce and pine trees may be at the 10 metre safe limit from your home but are they a threat to your neighbour?

If their house burns, yours might go as well. Firesmart information is available through the City of Whitehorse or Yukon Government websites.

Other possible emergencies for most Yukoners are: earthquakes, flooding, serious power outages and extreme cold spells. A wood stove and a small generator could save you and your home during an extended power outage in winter.

We should prepare for all of these emergencies but for most of us, fire is the main concern this week. Your emergency kit and a plan will work equally well for all emergencies.

To learn more about preparing for an emergency, search for "emergency preparedness" on the City of Whitehorse or Yukon government websites. Check the Jasper, Alberta emergency preparedness website as well for an excellent small town plan.

Ione Christensen is a member of Citizens for a Firesmart Whitehorse, a new informal organization that advocates for immediate and sustained actions to reduce the interface fire risk in Whitehorse.

An attempt to land overnight was aborted due to dense smoke and poor weather.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>The people were taken to temporary shelter Val d'Or, Que.</p><p>"This is typical of the missions that the air force's CC-130 Hercules crews are asked to undertake on a daily basis,'' acting 1 Canadian Air Division commander Brig.-Gen. Dwight Davies said in a statement.</p><p>"Hercules crews conduct a variety of tasks for Canadians from humanitarian operations, as in this case, through air-to-air refuelling of fighters conducting the NORAD mission.''</p><p>Firefighters have also come from several provinces to help out with the blazes.</p><p>"When we're hot and dry and shorthanded, we'd like to think they'd come and help us,'' said Bob Bruce, a duty officer with Saskatchewan Environment. Saskatchewan has sent more than 50 people to help out.</p><p>The reciprocal exchange of people, machines and equipment is made through the mutual aid resource sharing agreement.</p><p>The agreement is managed by the Canadian Forest Fire Centre in Winnipeg and sets out standardized rates and conditions for such exchanges.</p><p>It also details national training and equipment standards and allows for the development of joint fire management research projects.</p><p>Having everything in place means an exchange can happen on very short notice.</p><p>"In this case, we were ready in 24 hours,'' said Bruce, who left for Quebec from Prince Albert, Sask., with 25 others on Monday.</p><p>One person on the same plane as Bruce expected to be on familiar ground even though he's never been to Quebec.</p><p>"It's all the (Canadian) Shield,'' said Darryl McKenzie, from Southend, Alta., about 375 kilometres northeast of Prince Albert.</p><p>McKenzie said his region has lots of places where the peat moss is just as thick and they've had many huge, dangerous fires over the years.</p><p>"Hopefully we do good work for them,'' said McKenzie of the Quebec mission.</p><p>A group of three aircraft and related personnel have also been sent to Quebec from Saskatchewan.</p><p>(CP-Prince Albert Daily Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:51MD-59M1-JCBG-92X0-00000-00US sends firefighting team, fire retardants to help Israel contain its worst-ever forest fire2010-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisFOREIGN GENERAL NEWSUS sends firefighting team, fire retardants to help Israel contain its worst-ever forest fireAP

WASHINGTON _ The U.S. is sending a team of expert firefighters and supplies to Israel to help the country contain the worst forest fire in its history, Obama administration officials said Friday.

President Barack Obama discussed the deadly fire with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during a telephone call from Air Force One after it departed from Afghanistan. Obama had made an unannounced holiday visit to U.S. troops there.

The blaze has killed at least 41 people and displaced thousands.

Nancy Lindborg, assistant administrator for democracy, conflict and humanitarian assistance at the U.S. Agency for International Development, said a three-person U.S. Forest Service team experienced in aerial firefighting was en route to Israel and should arrive during the weekend.

At Israel's request, the U.S. also is sending 45 metric tons of fire retardant and 12,000 litres of foam. The chemicals are used to fight fires from the air and on the ground.

The U.S. also is trying to fulfil Israel's request for aircraft, said Dan Shapiro, a National Security Council official.

During the conversation with Netanyahu, Obama offered condolences for the loss of life, National Security Council aide Ben Rhodes told the reporters travelling with the president.

Rhodes also said the Pentagon was mobilizing National Guard members and equipment that can be used to fight fires.

urn:contentItem:7Y1S-1VW1-2R6R-54SB-00000-00Staffing problem may have led to Halifax forest fire that destroyed homes: CBC2010-03-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisATLANTIC REGIONAL NEWSStaffing problem may have led to Halifax forest fire that destroyed homes: CBCCP

HALIFAX _ An email written by a Halifax fire chief suggests a staffing problem may have led to a raging forest fire last spring that destroyed several homes and forced 1,100 residents to flee.

The CBC reported Wednesday that a Halifax Fire Service crew went on April 29 to extinguish a brush fire caused by a campfire off the Herring Cove Road on the outskirts of the city.

They put the fire out and returned the next morning to check for possible flareups.

At 11 a.m., the crew decided it was safe to return to their fire station for lunch, but when lunch was over they couldn't return immediately to the woods to check the site again.

In an email obtained by the CBC, Chief Bill Mosher wrote that the crew had to ''arrange for a cover and that may have delayed their return to the scene of the original fire.''

''A cover'' means the crew had to get another crew to mind the station before they could leave.

At 1:45 p.m., a 911 call reported smoke coming from the area before the crew could return.

The fire quickly spread and raged out of control for two days.

Halifax Regional Fire Service told the CBC that despite the reference to a delay in Mosher's email, everything went according to procedure and it had no bearing on the fire.

"It is the rays of light passing through the (dust) particles."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Canadian Press</p></bodyText></section><p>The fine dust particles in the smoke left a film on cars throughout Montreal. The city's public health authority issued a warning to senior citizens, children and people with respiratory problems to remain inside. They also recommended that people refrain from physically exerting activities.</p><p>Quebec's forest fire protection service said the smoke is coming from a fire that has been burning since July 2 in the region of Nemiscau, near James Bay. That fire prompted the evacuation of 500 aboriginal people from the village of Nemaska on Friday.</p><p>Although the Nemiscau fire is the most noticeable of 43 fires burning in northern Quebec, it is not the most severe.</p><p>A fire north of Lac St-Jean -- between the Manicouagan Reservoir and Mistassini River -- has burned about 650 square kilometres of forest and is currently considered out of control, one of 10 fires in the area with such a designation.</p><p>"Those are fires we basically have to leave alone for the meantime," said Eric Santerre of the provincial forest fire protection service, noting the smoke is too thick for planes to travel through it. "We need rain to bring down the amount of smoke before we can go in."</p><p>Santerre said there is no rain forecast for the area until at least Thursday, "so it won't be easy."</p><p>Only 15 square kilometres of Quebec forest has been claimed by forest fires at the beginning of July, but that number is now at 1,083 square kilometres, Santerre said.</p><p>The average for this time of year is urn:contentItem:5W7W-XCK1-F103-308D-00000-00Evacuations from Pikangikum First Nation hit 1,500 as nearby wildfire rages2019-06-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:07ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 0Evacuations from Pikangikum First Nation hit 1,500 as nearby wildfire rages

The Canadian Armed Forces says its airlift of evacuees from Pikangikum is expected to continue today because of the wildfire that is still raging near the northern Ontario First Nation.

The military said in a release late last night that it flew another 640 residents out Saturday aboard Hercules transport planes - taking them to Sioux Lookout and Kapuskasing.

It said about 15-hundred members of the fly-in community 500 kilometres northwest of Thunder Bay - those most at risk to the effects of smoke from the wildfire - have been evacuated so far.

Officials said the fire grew to about 36 square kilometres yesterday, but favourable winds were keeping it away from the community.

There is no rain in today's Environment Canada forecast, however, periods of rain and showers are expected both tomorrow and Tuesday.

Alvin Fiddler, grand chief of the Nishnawbe Aski Nation, which represents 49 First Nation communities across northern Ontario, has said the forest fire has damaged the broadband communications line running through the area, knocking out phone and internet service.

Environment Canada has issued a special air quality statement for the Pikangikum area, warning that high levels of air pollution are possible due to smoke from the fire.

"Children, seniors and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk," the agency said.
